<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200486609/mark">Mark T </a> EXPERT May 29, 2011

Thank you for your question.

I am sorry you are having a problem with the tractor. Next time the tractor dies, I recommend checking for spark at the spark plug. To check for spark remove the spark plug. Then reconnect the spark plug wire to the spark plug. With insulated pliers, hold the base of the spark plug against a clean blot head. While you are holding the spark plug in that position, have someone turn the engine over. When the engine is turning, you should see a spark from the spark plug. If you do not see a spark, I suspect the problem is a defective ignition coil. The coil can be purchased from out parts website: <a href="http://www.searspartsdirect.com?MML=MMLxexpertxmerch"> Sears Parts Direct </a> . When installing the new coil, make sure the gap between the flywheel and the magnets is .012.

I hope this is helpful. Please reply below with more details and I will be happy to assist you.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

If you do not feel confident repairing this problem yourself, then you can have it repaired at your home by a Sears technician. Here is a link for the website: <a href="http://services.sears.com/shs/category/repair?MML=MMLxexpertxmerch">Sears Home Services </a> .

Thank you for using Manage my life.

Mark T.

</div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200250662/bill">Bill H</a> May 29, 2011

James and Mark Thanks for the replies. Mark I think you have the solution. When I got it going this time and it quit I checked for spark and found none on either side. Should I just order the "Armature" #394891 (replaces 394988) at $55.11 or should I also order the "Trigger Coil Assembly" #394970 at $21.50 and 2 of the Spark Plug "Caps" #221798 @ $4.19 each? By the way, before I started it I vacuumed and blew out any debris from the flywheel, heads etc. I noticed before it quit that it seemd to smell real hot but I know that these engines do run hot. The oil evel was fine...is the heat a concern? Thanks, Bill

</div>

<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200486609/mark">Mark T </a> EXPERT May 30, 2011

Bill thanks for the reply. I recommend replacing the armature. It is part number 394891 and can be ordered from Sears parts direct. when installing the new armature set the gap between the flywheel magnet and the armature to .010 to .012. If you had not cleaned the cooling fins before now, make sure all of the fins around the cylinder and heads are cleaned. You might have to remove some of the covers to clean along the sides. The air from the flywheel passing over the fins is what cools the engine. It is best to run the engine at full speed to dissipate more heat. Please let me know if this advice is helpful.

</div>
</div>
<div></div>
</div>

<div><a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/28043/sam"><img src="http://www.managemylife.com/images/2956/small/Sam_IMG_2179_small.jpg?1288964544" alt="" border="0" /></a>
<div>

Sam a

Expert

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/28043/sam">Sam A</a> EXPERT June 08, 2011

Hi Raymond I am sorry that no one answered you quickly. Mark is on vacation. If the blades are turning while you are cranking your tractor to start it, it could be one of two problems. First I would clean the top of the mower deck off and spray some lubricant on the belt tightner pivot bolt to make sure it is moving freely. If that is not the problem the clutch cable for turning the blades on is sticking in the cable sheath and if it has not completely worn out you can go from the front lever where the cable attaches and spray lubricant down the cable sheath hole and then work the cable back and forth to loosen. If the cable is about to break then it is worn out and will need to be replaced. The new cable part number: 175067 comes with instructions for installation and you can purchase it from: [Sears Parts Direct | www.searspartsdirect.com?sid=MMLxexpertxmerch] . I hope this will help. Thank you for using Manage My Life. Sam A.

<div>
<h1>I figure hammer and screwdrivers for sure, but what else?</h1>
</div>
</div>
<div></div>
<div>
<div>
<div><a href="http://www.searspartsdirect.com?SID=MMLxparts" target="_blank">Find Parts</a> - <a id="schedule_service" href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/questions/210923-tools-everyone-toolbox-1#%7C%7CnonSearsHomeServices%7Cfalse">Schedule Repair</a> - <a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/get_it_done/questions/210923/tools+everyone+toolbox?show_products=Y">Purchase Products</a></div>
<div>
<div><a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/13157/jim"><img src="http://www.managemylife.com/images/257/small/Jim_headshot.jpg?1270137367" alt="" border="0" /></a>
<div>

Manag...

Aficionado

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/13157/jim">ManageMyLifeJim</a> June 03, 2010

We always have the following: a tape measure, an assortment of nails and screws, work gloves, a Leatherman, duct tape, CrazyGlue, a staple gun, and then of course the little random odds and ends that you dont know where they come from and you dont know where they go but you are certain they are important

</div>
</div>
</div>

<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200142583/chris">ctrinco</a> June 03, 2010

My life saver has been a Craftsmen 19.2 Volt drill and circuler saw. 19.2 might be more power and larger in size then most simple DIY'ers need. But, all it takes is that one time...and it more then makes up for it.

I would also recommend a tape measure, a utility knife, a flashlight, needle nose pliers, regular pliers, an adjustable wrench, a small magnetic level, some pencils, sharpie markers, duct tape, electrical tape, zip ties, WD-40, and an optional cordless drill, socket sets (standard and metric), hand saw, and a speed square should get you well on your way.

<div><a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200204573/robert"><img src="http://c0.managemylife.com/mmh/61691/mmh/images/site_evolution/defaults/default_avatar.gif?1344245710" alt="" border="0" /></a>
<div>

Robrieke

Newbie

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200204573/robert">robrieke</a> June 19, 2010

Good question. It all depends on how often you plan to use them and how you use them. I have 3 toolboxes: 1 in my car, 1 small one at home, and 1 large one at home. Car toolbox: Wrenches for access to the battery and to remove the belts, screwdrivers, fuse pullers and fuses, duct tape, zip ties and a spare belt. Small home toolbox: 1 of each size phillips and flathead screwdriver, set of jewelers screwdrivers, 2 adjustable wrenches, 1 wrench roll, a set of sockets and socket wrench, hex keys, various pliers, tape measures, a small level, pen and pencil, a small inspection mirror and a small flashlight. Large home toolbox: Everything else. Having a small toolbox with the typical tools I use keeps it lightweight and easy to move around the house. If I will do anything more advanced, I can always get other tools from my big toolbox.

</div>
</div>
<div></div>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<div>

5 8 Ratings

</div>

<div><a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200476312/joe"><img src="http://c0.managemylife.com/mmh/61691/mmh/images/site_evolution/defaults/default_avatar.gif?1344245710" alt="" border="0" /></a>
<div>

Joe l...

Dabbler

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200476312/joe">Joe LittleBear</a> June 19, 2010

These tools are a must,,... " Vise Grip" locking pliers, ( one small - about 5 inches long , and one large---- 10 inches long with the curved jaws....) and the arc-joint adjustable pliers such as "Channelock ", ( one 10 inch pair----one 18 inch pair ) a sharp wood chisel ( 1/2 " or 3/4" wide ), a sharp "cold chisel " ( for cutting metal ) a set of "Pin punches " ( from 1/8 " diameter to 1/2 " diameter...) a sturdy pry bar....about 18" long....with a 90 degree bend at one end with claws for pulling nails----a straight or 30 to 45 degree angle on the other end.., a good quality hacksaw--- using 12 " blades.. capable of turning the blade 90 degrees..., TWO sets each of "combination " open-end X box-end wrenches----1/4" to 3/4 " or 1 " SAE sizes ( 6 mm to 19 mm Metric ) Adjustable wrench (open end ) one 6 " and one 10" Electric Drill with 1/2 " chuck, Drill bit set 1/8 " to 1/2 " twist drills... One pair of lever-action tin shears...

</div>
</div>
<div></div>
</div>
<div>
<div>

	<item>
		<title>Oven Light</title>
		<link>http://uxint-sears/community/questions/oven-light/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Aug 2012 23:35:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uxint-sears/community/?post_type=question&#038;p=157</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<div>
<h1>Oven light stays on for kenmore Electric range.</h1>
I recently bought a used Kenmore Smooth top electric range. I replaced the light bulb and the light stays on all the time? I did some research and not sure if its the door hinges. The door does close but not perfectly. thanks. Model number 79096322401. I called Sears and it was made in 2003 or 2004

</div>
</div>
<div></div>
<div>
<div>
<div>

4 2 Ratings

</div>

</div>
</div>
<div>
<div><a href="http://www.searspartsdirect.com?SID=MMLxparts" target="_blank">Find Parts</a> - <a id="schedule_service" href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/questions/280015-oven-light-stays-kenmore-electric-range#%7CRange%7CnonSearsHomeServices%7Cfalse">Schedule Repair</a> - <a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/get_it_done/questions/280015/Oven+light+stays+kenmore+Electric+range?show_products=Y">Purchase Products</a></div>
<div>
<div><a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200476879/alina"><img src="http://c0.managemylife.com/mmh/61691/mmh/images/site_evolution/defaults/default_avatar.gif?1344245710" alt="" border="0" /></a>
<div>

Alina...

Expert

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200476879/alina">Alina F. </a> December 15, 2011

A oven is definitely something we depend on and when it begins to malfunction it can be a huge inconvenience. While you are waiting for an expert to respond, I have attached some helpful links below that may provide information to assist you with your question.
<div>
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/questions/247230-light-oven-stays" target="_self"> http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/questions/247230-light-ov...</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/questions/251692-element-light-stays-time" target="_self"> http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/questions/251692-element-...</a></li>

<div><a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/28043/sam"><img src="http://www.managemylife.com/images/2956/small/Sam_IMG_2179_small.jpg?1288964544" alt="" border="0" /></a>
<div>

Sam a

Expert

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/28043/sam">Sam A</a> EXPERT December 19, 2011

Thank you for your question, on the oven light not going out with the oven door closed.

Yes! There was a service issue with the hinges not letting the door close enough to turn the light off.

It will require replacement of the oven door hinges.

The part number for the hinge kit is: 5304445529.

Here is the ordering information for replacing the hinges for the oven door below.

<a href="http://www.searspartsdirect.com/partsdirect/part-number/5304445529/0022/628&amp;pathTaken=partSearch&amp;blt=14&amp;prst=0&amp;shdPart=5304445529?sid=MMLxexpertxmerch">Hinge kit for oven door </a> .

There are instructions in the kit that show how to replace the new hinge kit.

Please let me know how it goes.

Sam A.

</div>
</div>
<div></div>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<div>

Sam A -thank you for the answer. MY followup question is that is takes 18 minutes to preheat to 400 degrees. Is that normal? Also if I replaced the hinge kit to take care of the oven light problem would speed up the amount of time it takes to preheat? I am wondering if I am losing heat because of the faulty hinge door. Thanks

</div>
</div>

Thank you for the update. Yes it should also retain more heat in the oven but 18 minutes is about normal for a range to pre-heat to 400 degrees. Sam A.

<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200654995/tim">navyflipper</a> March 12, 2012

hi, i have a Kenmore # 665.95775890 electric smooth top. i went to use the oven last night. instead of hitting the broiler button, to cook hamburgers, i hit the clean button, an the oven door was open. i tried hit broiler button and close the door, but by then the latch had moved to the right to lock the door, an the door wasn't closed.now i cant use the oven cause door wont close cause the latch wont move back to the left.it shows a code, E1-F5- an says to call for service, that the latch may need replacing,is there any way I can reset it on my own? i cant afford service right now

</div>
</div>
<div></div>
</div>
<div>
<div>
<div>

5 1 Ratings

</div>
<div><a id="rate_this_436024">Rate this!</a>
<ul>
	<li></li>
	<li><a title="1 star out of 5">1</a></li>
	<li><a title="2 stars out of 5">2</a></li>
	<li><a title="3 stars out of 5">3</a></li>

	<li><a title="5 stars out of 5">5</a></li>

<div>
<div>
<div><a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/28043/sam"><img src="http://www.managemylife.com/images/2956/small/Sam_IMG_2179_small.jpg?1288964544" alt="" border="0" /></a>
<div>

Sam a

Expert

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/28043/sam">Sam A</a> EXPERT March 13, 2012

Hello Tim! I would suggest that you try this and let me know if it worked. Open the oven door and push and hold the oven light switch button all the while you program the oven to self clean. After programming the range to the self-clean cycle wait 30 seconds and the cancel the self clean cycle, still holding in the oven door light switch another 30 seconds. This will simulate the oven door being closed. This should get the latch hook back to the home position and the error code should go away. You should know be able to operate the range normally. Please let me know how it went. Sam A.

</div>
</div>
<div></div>
</div>

<div>

<a href="http://www.managemylife.com/mmh/user_profile/2200654995/tim">navyflipper</a> March 14, 2012

2nd posting,I didnt see my 1st post, so resending....Hello Sam A, I read ur advice. Went to the stove an hit the off/cancel button to reset back to the clock, like it was before, I pushed the oven light switch, an went to push the clean button an heard a grinding sound an looked down an the latch was moving back to its home position. So simple its stupid...i have my stove back..I have my own Plumbing Service, an give lots of advice to save them a Service call, I lose money, but I gain a happy customer an maybe future jobs. Im glad thats happened to me,for once. THANK again, Tim from TJ Plumbing Services in Co. If u have a Plumbing Question, Email me. I'll do my best to help You

		<title> How do I find a repair center?      </title>

	<item>
		<title>How do I ask an expert a question?</title>
		<link>http://uxint-sears/community/questions/how-do-i-ask-an-expert-a-question/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 20 Aug 2012 03:47:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uxint-sears/community/?post_type=question&#038;p=261</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a>How do I ask an expert a question?</a>

1. Go to <a href="http://www.managemyhome.com/">http://www.managemyhome.com/</a>.
2. Log in or sign up in the upper right-hand corner. It?s free!
3. Click on the Answers tab in the red navigation bar at the top of the page.
4. Enter your question in the box and click Next to look at a list of similar questions for a possible answer<strong>.</strong>
5. If you don?t find an answer to your question, type a detailed description of the problem in the Add Details box. You can even add pictures to illustrate your problem by clicking Add Images. Click on Preview and if your question looks correct, click Submit Question.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Where can I purchase parts for a repair?</title>
		<link>http://uxint-sears/community/questions/where-cn-i-purchase-parts-for-a-repair/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 20 Aug 2012 03:48:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uxint-sears/community/?post_type=question&#038;p=262</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a>Where can I purchase parts for a repair?</a>

To search for parts, purchase parts or view repair diagrams for your appliance, visit <a href="http://www.searspartsdirect.com/">http://www.searspartsdirect.com/</a> or call Sears Parts Direct at 1-800-469-4663 to speak with a Parts Direct Specialist. Either way, you?ll need your model number and serial number.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Buying a new Fridge?</title>
		<link>http://uxint-sears/community/appliances/buying-a-new-fridge/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 22 Aug 2012 15:39:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uxint-sears/community/?p=696</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Getting started</h2>
<div>
<div>

Our latest tests of more than 250 refrigerators revealed an expanding array of options. There are more French-door bottom-freezers than ever and quite a few models with a fourth compartment between the refrigerator and freezer. We're also seeing new finishes and features, including extra-tall water dispensers and models that reach new highs for efficiency. All that variety mean there's definitely a refrigerator out there that's perfect for you. Our buying guide will help you zero on your precise needs and desires.

</div>
<div>
<h3><a name="featuresandfridgesexpand"></a>Features (and fridges) expand</h3>
<div>

High-end features, such as temperature controlled drawers, adjustable shelves, split shelves, and internal water dispensers, are increasingly available on even the most affordable refrigerators. Some come loaded with features, including through-the-door ice and water dispensers, LED interior lights, and dual evaporators designed to maintain optimal humidity in their fresh food sections.

</div>
</div>
<div>
<h3><a name="beyondenergystar"></a>Beyond Energy Star</h3>
<div>

As the program turns 20, a new Most Efficient designation has been rolled out for appliances that are roughly 10 percent more efficient than Energy Star models and at least 30 percent more than non-Energy Star ones. Choosing a Most Efficient refrigerator over a non-Energy Star model could save you roughly $200 during the life of the unit.

</div>
</div>
<div>
<h3><a name="checkthespecs"></a>Check the specs</h3>
<div>

Make sure the refrigerator fits your kitchen. Remember to factor in the door swing in relation to adjacent walls, cabinets, and other appliances. And leave at least a 1-inch clearance around the unit and the surrounding cabinetry to ensure adequate air flow.

</div>
</div>
<div>
<h3><a name="consideryourfoodshoppinghabits"></a>Consider your food-shopping habits</h3>
<div>

Do you do a big weekly shop or like to stock up on bulk purchases? Then you may need a larger capacity than the 19 to 22 claimed cubic feet that most manufacturers suggest for a typical family of four.

</div>
</div>
<div>
<h3><a name="useenergyguidelabelswisely"></a>Use EnergyGuide labels wisely</h3>
<div>

Don't look for the Energy Star alone, since efficiency standards vary by refrigerator type. A non-Energy Star-qualified top-freezer might actually be more efficient than a side-by-side with the label. For an apples-to-apples comparison, use the annual operating costs and the kilowatt-hours per year the refrigerator uses, which are listed on the yellow EnergyGuide label. Or check our Ratings, which are consistent between types, for efficiency and energy costs.

</div>
</div>
<div>
<h3><a name="dontbeafraidtohaggle"></a>Don't be afraid to haggle</h3>
<div>

Those who did saved a median of $93 on a large appliance, according to our latest reader survey of retailers. Checking market prices will help you negotiate, though basic courtesy often goes further with salespeople than hardball tactics. And skip extended warranties.

</div>
</div>
<div>
<h3><a name="considershoppingonline"></a>Consider shopping online</h3>
<div>

While most major appliances are still bought at walk-in stores, online sales hit nearly 10 percent in 2011, up from barely a blip a decade earlier, according to Ipsos, a market-research company. But you may still want to go to a showroom to check fit, finish, and features, and give the retailer a chance to match an online price.

</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>696</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-08-22 10:39:38</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-08-22 15:39:38</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>buying-a-new-fridge</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>trash</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	<item>
		<title>Advice from a Caterpillar</title>
		<link>http://uxint-sears/community/general/advice-from-a-caterpillar/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Sep 2012 17:22:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uxint-sears/community/?p=1807</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Caterpillar and Alice looked at each other for some time insilence: at last the Caterpillar took the hookah out of itsmouth, and addressed her in a languid, sleepy voice.

'Who are YOU?' said the Caterpillar.

This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation. Alicereplied, rather shyly, `I--I hardly know, sir, just at present--at least I know who I WAS when I got up this morning, but I thinkI must have been changed several times since then.'

`What do you mean by that?' said the Caterpillar sternly.`Explain yourself!'

`I can't explain MYSELF, I'm afraid, sir' said Alice, `becauseI'm not myself, you see.'

`I don't see,' said the Caterpillar.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>SupercalifragiliswhateverthehellthismeanscuzIdontlikeanyofyouuglybastardscuzyousmelllikepooppooppoopsuckapoop</title>
		<link>http://uxint-sears/community/general/supercalifragiliswhateverthehellthismeanscuzidontlikeanyofyouuglybastardscuzyousmelllikepooppooppoopsuckapoop/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 21 Sep 2012 19:49:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uxint-sears/community/?p=2031</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[An <strong>article</strong> (<a title="List of glossing abbreviations" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_glossing_abbreviations">abbreviated</a> <strong>ART</strong>) is a <a title="Word" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Word">word</a> (or <a title="Prefix" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prefix">prefix</a> or <a title="Suffix" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suffix">suffix</a>) that is with a <a title="Noun" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noun">noun</a> to indicate the type of reference being made by the noun. Articles specify the grammatical <a title="Definiteness" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Definiteness">definiteness</a> of the noun, in some languages extending to volume or numerical scope. The articles in the <a title="English language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language">English language</a> are <em>the</em> and <em>a/an</em>, and (in some contexts) <em>some</em>. <a title="A and an" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_and_an#Indefinite_article">'An' and 'a'</a> are modern forms of the Old English 'an', which in Anglian dialects was the number 'one' (compare 'on', in Saxon dialects) and survived into Modern Scots as the number 'ane'. Both 'on' (respelled 'one' by the Normans) and 'an' survived into Modern English, with 'one' used as the number and 'an' ('a', before nouns that begin with a consonant sound) as an indefinite article.

<a title="Parts of speech" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parts_of_speech#English">Traditionally in English</a>, an article is usually considered to be a type of <a title="Adjective" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adjective">adjective</a>. In some languages, articles are a special part of speech, which cannot easily be combined with other parts of speech. It is also possible for articles to be part of another part of speech category such as a <a title="Determiner (linguistics)" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Determiner_%28linguistics%29">determiner</a>, an English part of speech category that combines articles and demonstratives (such as 'this' and 'that').

In languages that employ articles, every <a title="Common noun" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_noun">common noun</a>, with some exceptions, is expressed with a certain <a title="Definiteness" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Definiteness">definiteness</a> (e.g., definite or indefinite), just as many languages express every noun with a certain <a title="Grammatical number" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammatical_number">grammatical number</a> (e.g., singular or plural). Every noun <em>must</em> be accompanied by the article, if any, corresponding to its definiteness, and the lack of an article (considered a <em><a title="Zero article" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_article">zero article</a></em>) itself specifies a certain definiteness. This is in contrast to other adjectives and determiners, which are typically optional. This obligatory nature of articles makes them among the most common words in many languagesin English, for example, the most frequent word is <em>the</em>.<sup id="cite_ref-0"><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Article_%28grammar%29#cite_note-0">[1]</a></sup>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2031</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-09-21 14:49:52</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-09-21 19:49:52</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>supercalifragiliswhateverthehellthismeanscuzidontlikeanyofyouuglybastardscuzyousmelllikepooppooppoopsuckapoop</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="general"><![CDATA[General]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>

		<title>What&#039;s the best fridge?</title>
		<link>http://uxint-sears/community/questions/whats-the-best-fridge/</link>

		<pubDate>Tue, 11 Sep 2012 04:58:58 +0000</pubDate>

	<item>
		<title>Q&amp;A Right: Summary_list_Widget</title>
		<link>http://uxint-sears/community/?post_type=widget&#038;p=1944</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 17 Sep 2012 17:09:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://uxint-sears/community/?post_type=widget&#038;p=1944</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
